statement.text: Type 2 endoleak is a complication following Endovascular Aortic Repair (EVAR) characterized by retrograde blood flow into the aneurysm sac through patent collateral branch vessels, most commonly lumbar arteries and the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).
statement.formal: Type 2 Endoleak: Persistent perfusion of aneurysm sac post-EVAR via retrograde flow through aortic side branches â†’ sac pressurization

explanation.intuition: After placing a stent-graft in an aortic aneurysm, some small side branches that branch off the aorta can still allow blood to flow backward into the space around the graft (the aneurysm sac), keeping it pressurized even though the main blood flow is now through the graft.
explanation.key_insight: Type 2 endoleaks are the most common type (occurring in 10-45% of EVAR cases) but generally have lower risk than Type 1 or 3 endoleaks because the pressure is lower and many resolve spontaneously within 6 months.
explanation.technical_details: The retrograde flow occurs because the branch vessels maintain patency and receive blood from collateral circulation. This creates a low-pressure circuit that fills the aneurysm sac. The hemodynamic significance depends on the number and size of feeding vessels and the outflow pathways.
common_misconceptions: Not all endoleaks require immediate intervention - many Type 2 endoleaks resolve spontaneously
Type 2 endoleaks are not caused by technical failure of the EVAR procedure
Presence of a Type 2 endoleak does not automatically mean EVAR failure - monitoring sac size is critical

definitions_glossary.endoleak: Persistent blood flow outside the stent-graft lumen but within the aneurysm sac after EVAR
definitions_glossary.EVAR: Endovascular Aortic Repair - minimally invasive procedure to treat aortic aneurysms using a stent-graft
definitions_glossary.aneurysm_sac: The dilated, weakened portion of the aortic wall that forms the aneurysm
definitions_glossary.retrograde_flow: Blood flowing in the opposite direction from normal physiologic flow
definitions_glossary.collateral_vessels: Alternative blood vessel pathways that develop or persist to maintain blood supply
definitions_glossary.lumbar_arteries: Paired segmental arteries that branch from the posterior abdominal aorta
definitions_glossary.inferior_mesenteric_artery: Major branch of abdominal aorta supplying left colon and rectum

clinical_features.risk_stratification: Lower risk than Type 1 or Type 3 endoleaks
clinical_features.typical_presentation: Usually asymptomatic, detected on surveillance imaging

definition.@value: Complication following EVAR characterized by retrograde blood flow into the aneurysm sac through patent collateral branch vessels, most commonly lumbar arteries and the inferior mesenteric artery

prerequisites.title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
prerequisites.reason: Must understand AAA to understand EVAR complications

prerequisites.title: Endovascular Aortic Repair
prerequisites.reason: Type 2 endoleak is a post-EVAR complication

related.relationship: Type 1 endoleak is more urgent due to attachment site failure
Type 3 endoleak indicates structural graft failure
Embolization is primary intervention for persistent Type 2 endoleaks

skos:related.skos:note: Type 1 endoleak is more urgent due to attachment site failure
Type 3 endoleak indicates structural graft failure
Primary intervention for persistent Type 2 endoleaks

validation.notes: Definition and clinical features verified against current practice guidelines

learning_objectives: Define Type 2 endoleak and distinguish from other endoleak types
Identify the anatomic source vessels for Type 2 endoleaks
Understand the natural history and clinical significance
Recognize when intervention is required versus observation
common_errors: Confusing Type 2 with Type 1 endoleaks (different pathophysiology and urgency)
Not recognizing that many Type 2 endoleaks resolve spontaneously
Inappropriate aggressive intervention for stable Type 2 endoleaks
clinical_pearls: Size matters: Monitor aneurysm sac diameter - intervention if sac grows >5mm
Time matters: Give at least 6 months for spontaneous resolution before intervention
Simple presence is not an indication - need sac expansion or symptoms

medicalCode.description: Other specified complications following procedures on circulatory system
medicalCode.note: Requires extension code to specify Type 2 endoleak
